comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This is in Clyde Street, Millers Point (street now demolished). The house on the left with the lamp is in this painting by Julian Ashton "Clyde St, Miller's Point " 1901 (AGNSW) - collection.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/results.do?id... Also in this 1893 etching by Livingston Hopkins (NLA) - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an8538706

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Another good find and location identification!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is an interesting article about the "Doomed streets of Sydney" which has a wonderful description of the people we see in these Rocks photos and the so-called Demolition Books of Sydney City Council. It also has several pictures of Clyde Street which seemed to have been a favourite with photographers and artists before its demolition. scan.net.au/scan/journal/display.php?journal_id=64 Another thing which strikes me about this series by the unnamed photographer, is that the subjects are shown as beautiful, clean, light, almost idyllic - far from the rat infested slums and dark satanic mills. The photographer had a very artistic eye and an interest in recording the commonplace, even the people who lived there. These images do not LOOK like a State Government record !

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: What can I say, beachcomberaustralia, I'm speechless! You have a good eye for the small details.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: The City of Sydney Archives and Sydney Harbour Foreshore Authority should be able to help you out with the latest date at which this would have been taken. CoSA & SHFA both have similar images in their collections. The demolitions in the area mainly happened due to the plague clearing in the area in the early 20th century. I would at a guess say that these images were taken between 1900-1910. The street was photographed for the demolition books in 1901 and is image 000/00077 in Archive Pix

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Many of the rocks images in public collections in this period were indeed taken by professional photographers. In many of the same area at the same date, you do see very well dressed clean children. Parents were obviously concerned about putting on their Sunday best for these images. But also there is discussion about how slummy these slums really were. See Grace Karskens The Rocks: Life in Early Sydney.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks for that agrippinamaior - I think this photo is1901 like others in the series by the unnamed photographer. Some are (thoughtfully) dated - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2844602875/ , www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2633070834/ . Do you have any knowledge or ideas about the Ashton paintings connection with several of these photos, notably www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2844602875/ ?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I was going to ask for somebody's help to find EXACTLY where Clyde Street was in Millers Point, but I just found it on this 1895 map, west of the Observatory - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... . Demolished to make way for Hickson Road (was that ever supposed to be a railway?). Perhaps Paul Keating would be interested in restoring Clyde Street as part of the Barangaroo project ?!

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Hi beachcomber. I think you're right about the date. There are some in the SLNSW, SHFA & PHM around the same date and I think some at least are by the same studio. It's been a while since I looked at them. I'm not sure if the Ashton paintings/etchings are connected with these images. i think that he may have been doing his etchings, at least, earlier - early to late 1890s I think. They were possibly just good viewpoints, which is why they seem similar. But I have to admit I haven't looked into the connection that much.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: I always look at images of Clyde St and think ... what if those streets around there were still in existence? how cool would that area be?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Thanks beachcomberaustralia, I wasn't aware of the Ashton image, though I know of several other artworks of Clyde Street. One is by Sydney Long. He also did an etching, though he mis-titled the impressions 'Windmill St., Old Sydney'. Anne Ryan, the Curator of Australian Prints at the AGNSW confirmed the inscriptions underneath the image are in the artist's own hand, therefore it is custom not to correct the title. Both works happened to be included in exhibitions simultaneously at the Mitchell Library and AGNSW in 2007. The other is by Samuel Elyard (see Susanna Evans' 'Historic Sydney as Seen by its Early Artists', p. 31.) More information on the history of Clyde Street can be found in Shirley Fitzgerald and Christopher Keating's wonderful history 'Millers Point: The Urban Village', pp. 26-27, 31-32, 52-53, & 67.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Golly. Clyde Street seems to have been popular with artists and photographers around 1901 - it is almost a cliché!

The idea I am trying to show is that the artist(s) and the unattributed photographer of these Rocks pictures were well acquainted.   Or maybe even that the artists painted from the photo images - Heaven forbid! 

Looking at these two cottages again reminds me of gingerbread houses in a child's fairy story book, with the shutters and strange perspective making the roof seem over large, like a cartoon.  Is that from using an unusual lens?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Julian Ashton also did a watercolour "Back of old house, Clyde St Miller's Point" in 1901-2 (AGNSW) - collection.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/collection/results.do?id... I am betting that State Records NSW has a similar image without an identifying title (as was this photo) somewhere in its collection. Watch this space!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: beachcomber - you may be interested in this report

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia - The Mitchell Library attribute this photo and the collection it is from, 'Views taken during Cleansing Operations, Quarantine Area, Sydney, 1900' (commonly known as The Plague Albums - there are 6 of them, all digitised) to John Degotardi Jr. under the supervision of George McCredie. So, did Julian Ashton know either of these two men? ...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: It's great that we have so much information on streets in Sydney that not longer exist and  we are lucky to have images of  these street so we can see what The Rocks lookes like prior to redevelopment.  I agree The Rocks would have a lot more charm if those streets and gingerbread cottages still existed. Thanks for all the great comments.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks pellethepoet - there is the same photo at the link you posted, Vol. VI, No. 22 (Digital Order No. a147350) "350. Nos. 22 and 24 Clyde-street". I imagine 22 is the 'gingerbread' house on the left. I notice with a great deal of interest that the previous photo in the album, No. 349, closely matches the Julian Ashton painting mentioned at the top of this discussion. Volume VI link (see thumbnail page 3) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=413023&...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Yes beachcomberaustralia, very close indeed. I dare say some of the children depicted in Ashton's work are also in the sequence of photos.

In the Ashton work, do you think that might be a clothes drying pole at an angle from the balcony?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Yes, I think you are right pellethepoet.  Many of the pictures of this street seem to show various ingenious contraptions for drying clothes.

comment.author: 55838406@N03
comment._content: It is interesting to see photos of clyde st millers point. Doing family history, my great grandfather was born at a residence in clyde st millers point in 1871. It helps give perspective to the family situation. His father was presumably still working on the ships plying the east coast trade at the time. thanks for making the photos more accessable on the net.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: A summary of the known views of Clyde Street: THE PHOTOGRAPHS 4-6 Clyde Street, The Rocks (1900) SRNSW No. 2 Clyde Street (1900) by John Degotardi Jr. SLNSW Clyde-street, from No. 18, looking north (1900) by John Degotardi Jr. SLNSW Nos. 22 and 24 Clyde-street (1900) by John Degotardi Jr. SLNSW <<< *the above photo Terraces, Clyde St (East side), Miller's Point (1 April 1901) CSA Terraces, Clyde St, Miller's Point (1 April 1901) CSA Terraces, Clyde St, Miller's Point (1 April 1901) CSA THE ART Clyde Street (c.1901) by Sydney Long SLNSW Windmill St., old Sydney (1928) by Sydney Long AGNSW <<< *mis-titled by the artist Clyde St, Miller's Point (1901) by Julian Ashton AGNSW Back of old house, Clyde St Miller's Point (c.1895) by Julian Ashton AGNSW Clyde Street, Miller's Pt. by Alfred Coffey AGNSW Clyde Street, Millers Point, The Rocks (1893) by Livingston Hopkins NLA Back view of dwellings in Clyde Street (1902) by Fred Leist NGA Clyde Street, Millers Point by Samuel Elyard (see Susanna Evans, 'Historic Sydney as Seen by its Early Artists', (Lane Cove, NSW : Doubleday, 1983) p. 31

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Here's one I haven't seen before. A beautiful image - there's such a European sensibility to it. But where on Clyde Street did this courtyard branch off? Clyde Street, The Rocks [SRNSW: 4481_a026_000910] [UPDATE 16.09.11: This courtyard has been revealed to be the entrance to Parle's Buildings, off Bettington Street - not Clyde Street as originally captioned.]

comment._content: @ julemaq - How very interesting for you! Some of the people in these photos may well be your relatives.
